timeline.bodyText: This violates the current behavior. A HHCode encodes the lower left corner of its cell, not the cell center.
timeline.author: hbs

timeline.bodyText: Missing javdoc explaining what the method does
timeline.author: hbs

timeline.bodyText:
This is disturbing since the conversion from a list of arguments does not use the same convention as the conversion from a single argument.
It is probably better to introduce new functions which manipulate GEOCELLS rather than piggy back on HHCODE functions.
timeline.author: hbs

replies.bodyText: I made this change to mirror the behavior of GEOHASH->. Do you suggest removing that from both HHCODE-> and GEOHASH-> and making a new function of that?
replies.author: ftence

replies.bodyText: This is ok for STRING HHCodes which given their length can be interpreted as geo cells, but numerical HHCodes are different from Geo Cells which are derived from HHCodes but have a resolution prefix. Considering that a LONG appearing in a list is a Geo Cell but a LONG appearing by itself is a HHCode is what is disturbing.
replies.author: hbs

replies.bodyText:
I understand what you mean.
Currently HHCODE-> consider Long HHCodes to be of resolution 32 (so not Geo Cells) but that does not make sense to convert a list of resolution 32 HHCodes to a GeoXPShape, in fact that's not even possible without approximating.
->HHCODELONG converts a GeoXPShape to a list of Long GeoCell which is, as you said, mixing different concepts.
I will fix that and introduce ->GEOCELLS and GEOCELLS-> to convert a GeoXPShape to a list of Long or vice versa.
replies.author: ftence

timeline.message: Clearly differenciate functions handling hhcodes from those handling geocells

timeline.bodyText: Why not consider a STRING or BYTES HHCode as a GeoCell here? HHCODETO is more generic than this class to this respect.
timeline.author: hbs
hbs

timeline.bodyText: Why keep this here when GEOCELLS-> actually does the job?
timeline.author: hbs

timeline.message: Introduce conversion functions from/to GeoXPShape and Geo Cells

timeline.author: hbs

timeline.bodyText: This is kind of ugly, mixing a cast and autoboxing. Better to explicitely do ((Long) top).longValue()
